column1: Why does Kailath introduce state variables?
column2: To describe system behavior using a finite-dimensional internal representation that evolves in time and determines future behavior.
column3: Differential equations describe input–output behavior, not internal structure.

column1: What problem with differential equations does the state-space model address?
column2: Differential equations do not explicitly represent internal system memory or structure; state-space models do.
column3: Many different internal systems can share the same differential equation.

column1: What is Kailath’s definition of the state?
column2: A minimal set of variables whose value at time t0, together with the input for t ≥ t0, uniquely determines the system’s future behavior.
column3: “Minimal” here is conceptual, not yet algebraic minimality.

column1: What is the standard continuous-time linear state equation?
column2: ẋ(t) = A x(t) + B u(t)
column3: Linearity is with respect to both state and input.

column1: What is the output equation in a standard state-space model?
column2: y(t) = C x(t) + D u(t)
column3: The output is a linear function of the state and input.

column1: Why is the state usually not directly measurable?
column2: Because the state is a mathematical construct; only the output is constrained by measurement.
column3: State variables are chosen for convenience and structure.

column1: What does linearity of a state-space system mean?
column2: The system obeys superposition with respect to both initial conditions and inputs.
column3: This is stronger than linearity of an input–output differential equation alone.

column1: What does time invariance mean in state-space form?
column2: The matrices A, B, C, D do not depend explicitly on time.
column3: Time shifts of inputs produce time-shifted outputs.

column1: How does the solution of a linear state equation decompose?
column2: Into (i) a homogeneous (free) response due to the initial state, and (ii) a forced response due to the input.
column3: This decomposition is linear.

column1: What object propagates the state in time for zero input?
column2: The state transition matrix Φ(t) = e^{At}.
column3: It captures internal dynamics of the system.

column1: Over what field is the solution space of a linear state equation a vector space?
column2: Over the field of real or complex numbers, depending on whether real or complex-valued signals are admitted.
column3: Linearity holds with respect to initial conditions and inputs.

column1: Why does the solution set form a vector space (conceptually)?
column2: Because the governing equations are linear in the unknown functions and the forcing/input.
column3: This is independent of physical interpretation.

column1: What is a state transformation?
column2: An invertible change of variables x = T z where T is nonsingular.
column3: This changes representation, not behavior.

column1: How do the system matrices transform under x = T z?
column3: A is similar to A'.

column1: What properties are invariant under state transformations?
column2: Input–output behavior (transfer function) and internal dynamics up to similarity.
column3: Coordinates are not invariant; eigenvalues of A are.

column1: Why is the state representation not unique?
column2: Because infinitely many similarity-related realizations represent the same input–output behavior.
column3: This leads to canonical forms later.

column1: Why is a differential equation not the same as a realization?
column2: A differential equation specifies input–output behavior, while a realization specifies an internal state structure.
column3: Many realizations can correspond to the same differential equation.

column1: Why is it wrong to think the state is always “the output of integrators”?
column2: State variables need not correspond to physical integrators or stored energy in general.
column3: This misconception causes trouble when mapping abstract systems to networks.

column1: Which Chapter 2 concept underpins controllability later?
column2: The idea that the state captures the system’s internal degrees of freedom.
column3: Controllability asks whether inputs can move the state.

column1: Which Chapter 2 idea is essential for minimality later?
column2: Equivalence under similarity transformations.
column3: Minimality is defined over equivalence classes of realizations.

column1: In passive RLC networks, what does the state typically correspond to?
column2: Energy storage variables (inductor currents and capacitor voltages), up to linear transformation.
column3: This is a special case of the general state concept.

column1: Why does Kailath’s definition of state not assume energy storage?
column2: Because state is an abstract dynamical construct; energy interpretation is model-dependent.
column3: Important when comparing general LTI systems with passive networks.

column1: In a one-port immittance model, what plays the role of input and output?
column2: Input: current or voltage. Output: the conjugate terminal variable (voltage or current).
column3: This maps immittance to state-space I/O form.

column1: Why is an immittance description inherently input–output?
column2: Because it eliminates internal variables and retains only terminal behavior.
column3: State-space reintroduces internal structure.

column1: Why do multiple RLC networks realize the same immittance?
column2: Because many state-space realizations are equivalent under similarity transformations.
column3: Non-uniqueness of internal structure is expected.

column1: What does a change of state coordinates correspond to in network terms?
column2: A redistribution/reinterpretation of internal variables without changing terminal behavior.
column3: E.g., changing loop-current or node-voltage coordinates.

column1: What does minimality mean in state-space terms?
column2: The realization has the smallest possible state dimension for the given input–output behavior.
column3: Purely algebraic in general.

column1: What does minimality correspond to in passive network synthesis?
column2: The smallest number of energy storage elements (L and C) in any realization.
column3: Subject to PR/passivity constraints.

column1: Why does similarity equivalence not imply identical network topology?
column2: Because similarity preserves behavior, not physical interconnection.
column3: Topology carries extra structure beyond state equivalence.

column1: What additional constraints distinguish ladder realizations from general realizations?
column2: Structural constraints on A, B, C (e.g., Jacobi/tridiagonal A with end-point port coupling).
column3: Not imposed in Chapter 2.

column1: Why can a minimal realization still fail to be passively realizable?
column2: Because minimality alone does not enforce positive-realness/passivity constraints.
column3: PR adds inequalities beyond rank conditions.

column1: What extra structure must a realization have to correspond to a passive RLC network?
column2: A compatible storage function (energy) and dissipation structure.
column3: Port-Hamiltonian/PR theory formalizes this.

column1: Why does Brune synthesis extract sections iteratively?
column2: Because not all PR systems admit a ladder (Jacobi) realization directly.
column3: Brune steps handle the non-ladder part.

column1: How does equivalence of realizations explain multiple Brune realizations?
column2: Different synthesis paths produce different but equivalent internal realizations.
column3: Non-uniqueness persists under synthesis choices.

column1: Why is Kailath’s abstract state concept essential for understanding PR synthesis?
column2: Because PR synthesis is about choosing a realization with additional structural constraints.
column3: State-space defines the universe; PR selects an admissible subset.

column1: What is the key limitation of immittance-only reasoning in synthesis?
column2: It hides internal structure needed to enforce passivity constructively.
column3: State-space exposes that structure.

column1: ⚠️ Why is it dangerous to assume every state variable corresponds to stored energy?
column2: Because state is an abstract dynamical variable; only passive realizations admit an energy interpretation.
column3: Kailath’s theory applies to systems without physical storage.

column1: ⚠️ When is the “state = inductor currents & capacitor voltages” intuition valid?
column2: Only for passive RLC realizations, and even then only up to linear transformation.
column3: It is a special realization, not a general truth.

column1: ⚠️ Why is it wrong to think a differential equation defines the state?
column2: Because a differential equation specifies behavior, not internal structure.
column3: Many inequivalent realizations correspond to the same equation.

column1: ⚠️ What is lost when moving from state-space to an immittance description?
column2: Information about internal structure and energy flow.
column3: Immittance is input–output only.

column1: ⚠️ Why does minimal state dimension not guarantee a minimal passive network?
column2: Because algebraic minimality ignores positivity/passivity constraints.
column3: PR realizability adds inequalities beyond rank conditions.

column1: ⚠️ What mistake arises from equating McMillan degree with element count?
column2: Not all states correspond one-to-one with physical storage elements in an arbitrary realization.
column3: Synthesis imposes additional structure.

column1: ⚠️ Why does similarity equivalence not preserve network topology?
column2: Topology encodes physical interconnection, not just transfer behavior.
column3: Similarity preserves I/O behavior, not graphs.

column1: ⚠️ Why is “changing state coordinates” not benign in synthesis?
column2: Because it can destroy passivity/ladder-realizability by wrecking structural constraints.
column3: Jacobi/ABQ structure is not similarity-invariant.

column1: ⚠️ Why is assuming a Jacobi (ladder) realization dangerous?
column2: Because not all PR systems admit Jacobi structure; some require Brune sections.
column3: Ladders are a restricted subclass.

column1: ⚠️ What incorrect inference arises from “A is tridiagonal”?
column2: That the system must be ladder-realizable and passive.
column3: Tridiagonal structure alone is insufficient.

column1: ⚠️ Why is it dangerous to treat all linear-system structures as vector spaces?
column2: Some structures are naturally modules over rings, not vector spaces over fields.
column3: This matters in factorization and realization theory.

column1: ⚠️ Where does hidden algebra creep into Chapter 2?
column2: In assumptions about linearity, the underlying field, and equivalence.
column3: Later chapters rely on these implicitly.

column1: ⚠️ Why is positive-realness not purely an I/O property in synthesis?
column2: Realizability requires compatible internal energy/dissipation structure.
column3: PR ≠ arbitrary stable transfer function.

column1: ⚠️ What is the core mistake behind “state-space first, synthesis later”?
column2: Assuming any realization can be post-processed into a passive one.
column3: Synthesis is structural, not cosmetic.

column1: ⚠️ What is the fundamental danger when reading Kailath as a circuit theorist?
column2: Over-interpreting abstract linear systems as physical networks.
column3: Kailath defines the universe; PR selects a constrained subset.

column1: What problem does minimality solve in state-space theory?
column2: It identifies the smallest internal state dimension that realizes a given input–output behavior.
column3: Without minimality, realizations can be arbitrarily redundant.

column1: Why is minimality not defined directly in Chapter 2?
column2: Because it requires controllability/observability tools introduced later.
column3: Chapter 2 establishes equivalence first.

column1: What does it mean for two realizations to be equivalent?
column2: They produce identical input–output behavior for all admissible inputs (and consistent initial conditions).
column3: Minimality is defined over equivalence classes.

column1: What does minimality say informally about the state space?
column2: No state variable is dynamically redundant.
column3: Every state contributes to controllable/observable behavior.

column1: Why is minimality an algebraic property?
column2: Because it is characterized by rank/structural conditions rather than particular coordinate choices.
column3: Anticipates invariants.

column1: Why does realization theory require invariants beyond eigenvalues?
column2: Because input–output behavior depends on poles/zeros of transfer functions, not just internal eigenvalues.
column3: Eigenvalues alone do not classify transfer behavior.

column1: What role does Smith–McMillan form play conceptually?
column2: It classifies transfer matrices up to unimodular equivalence (input/output basis changes).
column3: I/O analogue of similarity for state.

column1: What does Smith–McMillan degree correspond to?
column2: The minimal state dimension of any realization of the transfer matrix.
column3: Bridges transfer invariants and state dimension.

column1: Why can Smith–McMillan invariants not be changed by state transformations?
column2: They depend only on the transfer function, not on internal coordinates.
column3: They are realization-independent.

column1: In passive network synthesis, what does Smith–McMillan degree often correspond to?
column2: The minimum number of energy storage elements needed (subject to PR constraints).
column3: Correspondence is constrained by realizability.

column1: What is meant by a Jacobi realization?
column2: A realization whose state matrix A has tridiagonal (path-like) structure.
column3: A structural constraint, not just a coordinate choice.

column1: Why is Jacobi structure significant?
column2: It corresponds to nearest-neighbor coupling in the state.
column3: This anticipates ladder interconnections.

column1: Why is Jacobi structure not similarity-invariant?
column2: Similarity transforms generally destroy sparsity patterns.
column3: Structure ≠ behavior.

column1: Can every minimal realization be put into Jacobi form?
column2: No.
column3: Jacobi realizations form a strict subset of minimal realizations.

column1: What extra property must hold for a Jacobi realization to exist (beyond minimality)?
column2: Compatibility between dynamics, port placement, and positivity/passivity structure.
column3: PR structure often supplies the missing constraints.

column1: What does a ladder network correspond to in state-space terms?
column2: A Jacobi realization with end-point input/output coupling (end-collocated ports).
column3: A very special realization class.

column1: Why are ladder networks restrictive?
column2: They enforce both algebraic and topological constraints.
column3: Most PR systems violate at least one.

column1: Why does failure of Jacobi structure motivate Brune synthesis?
column2: Because Brune sections compensate for missing ladder structure while preserving PR behavior.
column3: Brune handles non-ladder parts iteratively.

column1: What does each Brune section represent abstractly?
column2: A controlled relaxation of ladder/Jacobi constraints while maintaining passivity/PR behavior.
column3: A structural repair step.

column1: What is the deepest connection between Jacobi form and PR systems (preview)?
column2: Jacobi form corresponds to structurally regular PR systems; irregularity forces non-ladder synthesis.
column3: Links to your regular/nonregular program.

column1: What does the triple (A, B, Q) represent in energy-based realizations?
column2: A: dynamics; B: port coupling; Q: energy metric (storage).
column3: Energy structure is additional; not assumed in Chapter 2.

column1: What role does Q play in passive systems?
column2: It defines a quadratic storage function H(x) = xᵀ Q x.
column3: Passivity typically requires Q ⪰ 0.

column1: Why does a general state-space realization not come with a natural Q?
column2: Because an energy interpretation is an extra constraint, not implied by linearity.
column3: Separates abstract LTI from physical networks.

column1: What kind of condition links A, B, Q in passive systems (high level)?
column2: Dissipation inequalities involving AᵀQ + QA and the port terms via B.
column3: These encode positive-realness.

column1: Why is ABQ structure not similarity-invariant in general?
column2: Similarity transforms typically change the energy metric; sparsity/energy structure can be destroyed.
column3: Only special transforms preserve Q nicely.

column1: What does “end-collocated” mean in ABQ realizations (preview)?
column2: Inputs and outputs couple at boundary states of the energy structure.
column3: This aligns naturally with ladders.

column1: Why do Jacobi realizations naturally support ABQ structure (preview)?
column2: Nearest-neighbor coupling aligns with localized energy storage and boundary ports.
column3: This is why ladders are special.

column1: Why can failure of ABQ/Jacobi structure force Brune sections (preview)?
column2: Extra coupling is needed to preserve passivity/PR while realizing the same I/O behavior.
column3: Brune steps repair the energy/structure iteratively.

column1: Give a state-space realization of y¨ + a y˙ + b y = u.
column3: One of infinitely many realizations.

column1: Why is the above realization not unique?
column2: Any invertible linear transformation of x gives an equivalent realization with the same transfer function.
column3: Similarity changes coordinates, not behavior.

column1: What is the minimal state dimension of G(s) = 1/(s+1)?
column3: Single simple pole → McMillan degree 1.

column1: Give an easy 2-state realization of G(s)=1/(s+1) that is not minimal.
column2: Example idea: augment with a decoupled stable mode (adds a redundant state) while keeping the same I/O map.
column3: Non-minimal realizations contain unreachable or unobservable states.

column1: Is G(s)=1/(s+1) positive real?
column2: Yes (it has Re{G(jω)} ≥ 0 for all ω and is analytic in Re{s}>0).
column3: Good sanity-check example of a PR function.

column1: Is every minimal realization of a PR transfer function passive?
column2: No.
column3: Passivity is a structural property of a realization, not automatic from minimality.

column1: Give a simple 2×2 Jacobi A matrix pattern.
column2: A = [[a11, a12], [a12, a22]] (symmetric tridiagonal).
column3: For 2 states, tridiagonal means only one off-diagonal coupling.

column1: Why can’t every 2-state realization be made Jacobi by similarity?
column2: Similarity does not preserve sparsity; a generic A becomes dense under coordinate changes.
column3: Jacobi is a structural constraint.

column1: What does adding a Brune section change abstractly?
column2: It adds internal structure (often increasing state dimension) to maintain PR/passivity while realizing the I/O behavior.
column3: Think: structural repair step.

column1: Micro-check: what does similarity preserve, and what does it not preserve?
column2: Preserves transfer behavior (I/O map). Does not preserve topology, sparsity, ladder form, or a specific energy metric Q.
column3: Useful to prevent ‘coordinate = circuit’ mistakes.

column1: What is the state transition matrix Φ(t, t0) (continuous-time)?
column2: The linear map that propagates the state: x(t)=Φ(t,t0)x(t0) for zero input.
column3: For LTI systems Φ(t,t0)=e^{A(t-t0)}.

column1: What key property does the state transition matrix satisfy?
column2: Semigroup property: Φ(t2,t0)=Φ(t2,t1)Φ(t1,t0).
column3: Encodes composition of time evolution.

column1: What are Markov parameters (for an LTI state-space model)?
column2: Impulse-response coefficients: h0=D and hk=C A^{k-1} B for k≥1 (discrete-time); analogous moments in continuous-time expansions.
column3: They determine the I/O behavior locally in time / in a series expansion.

column1: What is the Hankel matrix built from Markov parameters?
column2: A matrix whose (i,j) entry is a Markov parameter h_{i+j} (or h_{i+j-1} depending on indexing).
column3: Hankel rank relates to minimal realization order.

column1: How are Markov parameters used for realization (high level)?
column2: They can be arranged into Hankel matrices whose rank reveals the minimal state dimension; factorization yields a realization.
column3: This is a precursor to subspace identification ideas.

column1: Why does Kailath distinguish canonical forms from controllability/observability forms?
column2: Canonical forms (controllable/observable) encode polynomial/companion structure via a special coordinate choice; controllability/observability forms encode the geometry of reachable/observable subspaces (and still apply when those properties fail).
column3: Two viewpoints: algebraic (companion/canonical) vs geometric (subspaces).

column1: What is the fundamental difference between a canonical form and a controllability (or observability) form?
column2: Canonical form: a specific coordinate representation chosen for algebraic convenience (often companion-matrix based). Controllability/observability form: a decomposition that exposes reachable/observable subspaces (structure), even if the system is not fully reachable/observable.
column3: Canonical = coordinate choice; controllability/observability form = structural decomposition.

column1: Why is the controllable canonical form considered special?
column2: It realizes the characteristic polynomial in companion form, making input→state propagation a shift chain and exposing denominator coefficients directly—useful for algebraic manipulation and state-feedback (pole placement) reasoning.
column3: Companion matrix / controller form highlights reachability chain.

column1: Why is the observable canonical form considered special?
column2: It is the dual companion realization that makes state→output structure explicit (observer chain), tying polynomial structure to the output map and supporting observer-style reasoning.
column3: Dual companion (Aᵀ,Cᵀ) viewpoint; output-oriented algebra.

column1: When do canonical (companion) forms stop being the right tool?
column2: When the system is not fully controllable or not fully observable (or when you need to expose which modes are unreachable/hidden). Canonical forms can hide uncontrollable/unobservable dynamics in their assumed full-rank structure.
column3: Canonical forms assume full reachability/observability; subspace forms diagnose failure.

column1: What problem does the controllability form solve that the controllable canonical form does not?
column2: It isolates the reachable subspace and explicitly separates uncontrollable modes, which is essential for decomposition and minimal realization reasoning when the system is not fully controllable.
column3: Reachable subspace geometry vs companion algebra.

column1: Why does the observability form matter if an observable canonical form exists?
column2: It isolates the observable subspace and explicitly separates unobservable (hidden) modes, which you cannot diagnose if you only work in a fully observable companion form.
column3: Observable-subspace geometry vs output companion algebra.

column1: If a system is controllable, must it be in controllable canonical form?
column2: No. Controllability is invariant under similarity transforms; controllable canonical form is just one convenient coordinate choice.
column3: Property vs representation.

column1: Does observability mean every state directly affects the output?
column2: No. Observability means each state affects the output through the dynamics over time (possibly indirectly), not necessarily instantaneously.
column3: Direct effect ≠ observable; observability is temporal.

column1: Does the observable form sum all feedback terms together with the input into the first integrator?
column2: No. In the observable-form signal-flow picture, output-derived injections are applied along the chain (into multiple junctions), not only at a single leftmost node.
column3: Vignette: observable form uses repeated injections along the chain.

column1: Why does Kailath insist on distinguishing controllability form from controllable canonical form?
column2: Because controllability form reveals reachable-subspace geometry even when the system is not fully controllable, while controllable canonical form is a companion realization that presumes full controllability.
column3: Becomes concrete in Kalman decomposition and minimal realization chapters.

column1: Why is observability form necessary even if an observable canonical form exists?
column2: Because observability form reveals the observable subspace and hidden modes even when the system is not fully observable; observable canonical form is a special companion representation that presumes full observability.
column3: Becomes concrete when separating hidden dynamics and building minimal realizations.

column1: What is the algebraic duality linking controllability and observability?
column2: Observability of (A,C) is equivalent to controllability of (Aᵀ, Cᵀ).
column3: Core duality used repeatedly in proofs and constructions.

column1: Structurally, what is the fan-out vs fan-in signature of controllable vs observable viewpoints?
column2: Controllable (controller) viewpoint emphasizes fan-out/reachability from the input along a shift chain; observable (observer) viewpoint emphasizes fan-in/information flow toward the output and repeated injections along the chain.
column3: Mnemonic for recognizing diagrams quickly.

column1: Which forms underpin the Kalman decomposition?
column2: Controllability and observability forms (the subspace-revealing decompositions), not the companion/canonical forms.
column3: Kalman decomposition is about reachable/observable subspaces.

column1: Why do controllability/observability forms matter even more for multivariable (MIMO) systems?
column2: Companion (canonical) forms tied to scalar polynomials do not generalize cleanly, while reachable/observable subspace decompositions do.
column3: Motivation strengthens when moving beyond SISO.
